newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy cabinet meeting brought forward to 1700 GMT.
newsitem.headline: Italy cabinet meeting brought forward to 1700 GMT.

text.p: The Italian cabinet meeting due later on Tuesday will start at 1700 GMT and not the originally planned 1800 GMT, the prime minister's office said in a statement.
The cabinet is expected to discuss all government decree laws due to expire before November 8.
Earlier this month Italy's high court ruled unconstitutional the practice by which cabinets have renewed decrees.
The ruling has yet to come into force and the government is racing to renew decrees which are about to expire, to win themselves breathing space.
Decrees take immediate effect but lapse unless they are ratified by parliament and passed into law within 60 days.

They were originally meant to be applied in extraordinary circumstances, but successive cabinets, faced with the slow pace of law-making in parliament, have in the past simply re-issued them with little or no change, renewing their life.

Deputy prime minister Walter Veltroni said earlier this month that while the ruling was justified, Italy could face paralysis unless parliament made a mammoth effort to enact more than 50 outstanding "repeat" decrees into law. -- Rome newsroom +396 6782501
